early.description: Born into an expeditionary crew, your earliest memories are of alien landscapes and scientific equipment.
At age seven, you assisted in basic data collection, showcasing your aptitude for science.
You developed a keen eye for environmental details, rarely missing anomalies.
An encounter with a hazardous environment taught you the importance of caution and protocol.
You learned to operate various instruments, demonstrating technical proficiency.
Witnessing the wonders of new worlds instilled in you a passion for exploration.
You customized equipment for better efficiency, showing ingenuity.
An experienced surveyor mentored you, teaching advanced techniques.
You formed a bond with another young surveyor, sharing discoveries and aspirations.
A close call with a planetary hazard sharpened your instincts and reflexes.
You began studying scientific texts, enhancing your knowledge.
An illness due to exposure tested your resilience and adaptability.
You discovered a significant environmental anomaly, fueling your curiosity.
A family member's reassignment prompted you to become more independent.
You started experimenting with data analysis, improving your skills.
An encounter with corporate overseers sparked your skepticism.
You developed physical strength through fieldwork in challenging conditions.

mid.description: You took on significant survey missions, analyzing complex environments.
A conflict with corporate interests led to increased tension and oversight.
You discovered valuable resources, facing ethical dilemmas about exploitation.
An offer to join a corporate team challenged your principles.
You began mentoring younger surveyors, passing on your expertise.
A personal injury forced you to adapt, relying more on intellect than physical ability.
You discovered evidence of environmental damage caused by corporate activities.
A colleague's betrayal led to increased caution and distrust.
You faced ethical choices when asked to withhold data.
An unexpected natural event tested your analytical skills.

late.description: Elevated to a leadership role, you coordinated major survey operations.
A significant discovery threatened the balance of the ecosystem, requiring decisive action.
You uncovered a corporate plot to exploit planetary resources, prompting difficult choices.
Faced with a moral dilemma, you had to choose between scientific integrity and corporate demands.
An opportunity to join an independent research group challenged your priorities.
You exposed illegal activities harming the environment, preventing further damage.
A personal tragedy prompted deep reflection on your career path.
You began to suffer from the psychological effects of isolation and ethical conflicts.
A movement to protect the planet gained momentum, and you had to decide your role.
You mentored a young surveyor, hoping to pass on your knowledge and values.
Environmental conditions worsened, making surveying increasingly challenging.
You authored a groundbreaking study on planetary environments.
An external threat, such as invasive species or natural disasters, endangered the planet.
You faced a critical decision when offered a chance to leave for a more stable assignment.
An unexpected alliance offered new possibilities but also new risks.
You considered the legacy you would leave and how to effect lasting scientific impact.
A technological advancement changed the dynamics of surveying, forcing you to adapt.
